```{r setup, include=FALSE}
#working directory
setwd("~/Documents/R_programming")

# Packages
library(tidyverse)
library(dplyr)


```

Essential dplyr functions
filter(): select specific rows of data based on conditions
select(): choose the columns you want to review
arrange(): sort your data rows based on column values

```{r eval=FALSE, include=FALSE}
# # Example of filter to select sales over $200
 sales_data <- data.frame(
   order_id = 1:10,
   order_date = as.Date("2021-01-01") + 0:9,
  sales_amount = c(30, 200, 150, 300, 120, 340, 240, 40, 500, 410)
)

 # Using `filter()`
 filtered_sales <- sales_data %>% filter(sales_amount > 200)

 print(filtered_sales)

#
# # Example Dataset `hr_data`
 hr_data <- data.frame(
   employee_id = 1:5,
  name = c("Alice", "Bob", "Charlie", "Diana", "Eve"),
  job_title = c("Manager", "Analyst", "Developer", "Designer", "Tester"),
   email = c("alice@example.com", "bob@example.com", "charlie@example.com", "diana@example.com", "eve@example.com")
 )

# Using `select()`
contact_list <- hr_data %>% select(name, job_title, email)

print(contact_list)




# Example Dataset `employee_data`
employee_data <- data.frame(
  employee_id = 1:4,
  name = c("Alice", "Bob", "Charlie", "Diana"),
  salary = c(70000, 55000, 62000, 68000)
)

# Using `arrange()`
sorted_employees <- employee_data %>% arrange(desc(salary))

print(sorted_employees)
```
